facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 194 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 194 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 27, 1964 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc.  First Appeal No.60 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 27, 1964 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. First Appeal No.60 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 27, 1964 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc.  First Appeal No.60 of 1960. N. Anand and Kailash Mehta, for the appellant.

facts.text: Naraindas is the appellant, brother of Vallabhdas and Durgaprasad (respondents 1 and 2), and son of Smt. Sukhrani (respondent No. 3).

anchor.surface_text: Naraindas, appellant is the brother of Vallabhdas and Durga- prasad, respondents 1 and 2 and son of Smt. Sukhrani, respondent No. 3. There were, some arbitration proceedings in 1932 between the appellant and respondents 1 to 3 on one side and Pannalal and Smt. Dulari Bahu on the other side.

facts.text: Arbitration proceedings in 1932 between appellant and respondents 1 to 3 on one side and Pannalal and Smt. Dulari Bahu on the other side.

anchor.surface_text: There were, some arbitration proceedings in 1932 between the appellant and respondents 1 to 3 on one side and Pannalal and Smt. Dulari Bahu on the other side. Those proceedings related to partition of property and a claim for maintenance allowance by Dulari Bahu.

facts.text: Proceedings related to partition of property and claim for maintenance allowance by Dulari Bahu.

anchor.surface_text: Those proceedings related to partition of property and a claim for maintenance allowance by Dulari Bahu. An award was given in those proceedings and was made a rule of the Court on 13-12-1933.

facts.text: Award given in 1932 proceedings made rule of the Court on 13-12-1933.

anchor.surface_text: An award was given in those proceedings and was made a rule of the Court on 13-12-1933. According to the award, Dulari Bahu was to get a maintenance allowance of Rs. 12/- per mensem from the appellant and his brothers .

facts.text: According to 1933 award, Dulari Bahu to get maintenance allowance of Rs. 12 per mensem from appellant and his brothers.

anchor.surface_text: According to the award, Dulari Bahu was to get a maintenance allowance of Rs. 12/- per mensem from the appellant and his brothers . A charge was created of the maintenance allowance on the house which fell as a result of partition to the share of the appellant and respondents 1 to 3.

facts.text: Charge created on the house allotted to appellant and respondents 1 to 3 for maintenance allowance.

anchor.surface_text: A charge was created of the maintenance allowance on the house which fell as a result of partition to the share of the appellant and respondents 1 to 3. It was also provided that if the appellant and his brothers failed to pay the monthly allowance, Dulari Bahu would, be entitled to get the house sold.

facts.text: If failed to pay, Dulari Bahu entitled to get house sold; Rs. 3000 from proceeds deposited in bank, interest to her, principal on death split Rs2000 to appellant brothers, Rs1000 to Pannalal.

anchor.surface_text: It was also provided that if the appellant and his brothers failed to pay the monthly allowance, Dulari Bahu would, be entitled to get the house sold. Out of the sale proceeds, Rs. 3,000/- were to be deposited in a bank on the companydition that the, amount of interest would be paid to Dulari Bahu but she would number be entitled to draw the principal amount. On Dulari Bahus death, Rs. 2,000/-out of Rs. 3,000/- would be paid to the appellant and his brothers and Rs. 1,000/- to Pannalal.

facts.text: Maintenance amount increased to Rs. 30 per mensem in suit decided on 8-10-1949.

anchor.surface_text: The amount of maintenance payable to Dulari Bahu was increased to Rs. 30/- per mensem in a suit brought by her and decided on 8-10-1949. As the appellant and his brothers did number pay the maintenance allowance to Dulari Bahu, she, in execution of her claim for maintenance allowance, got their houses situated at Jabalpur sold by Court auction.

facts.text: Appellant and brothers did not pay maintenance; Dulari got their houses at Jabalpur sold by court auction.

anchor.surface_text: As the appellant and his brothers did number pay the maintenance allowance to Dulari Bahu, she, in execution of her claim for maintenance allowance, got their houses situated at Jabalpur sold by Court auction. The houses were purchased for Rs. 22,000/- by Sitaram and Laxminarain, respondents 4 and 5.

facts.text: Houses purchased for Rs. 22,000 by Sitaram and Laxminarain, respondents 4 and 5.

anchor.surface_text: The houses were purchased for Rs. 22,000/- by Sitaram and Laxminarain, respondents 4 and 5. After obtaining the sale certificate, respondents 4 and 5 took proceedings for obtaining possession of the houses but they were resisted by respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Respondents 4 and 5 obtained sale certificate and took proceedings for possession, resisted by respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: After obtaining the sale certificate, respondents 4 and 5 took proceedings for obtaining possession of the houses but they were resisted by respondent No. 1. The appellant and his brothers further claimed that they had deposited some amount with respondents 4 and 5.

facts.text: Appellant and brothers claimed they deposited some amount with respondents 4 and 5.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and his brothers further claimed that they had deposited some amount with respondents 4 and 5. The appellant and his brothers and mother on one side and respondents 4 and 5 on the other side thereupon appointed four arbitrators, as per agreement dated 8th April, 1955.

facts.text: Agreement dated 8th April 1955 between appellant, brothers, mother and respondents 4 and 5 to appoint four arbitrators.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and his brothers and mother on one side and respondents 4 and 5 on the other side thereupon appointed four arbitrators, as per agreement dated 8th April, 1955. According to the agreement, respondents 4 and 5 would have numberclaim in the houses purchased by them in Court auction and the arbitrators would make award in respect of the amounts to be paid by either of the parties as well as regarding the maintenance allowance payable to Durga Bahu and Sukhrani Bahu.

facts.text: Arbitrators gave award dated 20th October 1956 providing for amounts payable to different parties.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrators thereafter gave their award dated 20th October, 1956 wherein they made provision for the amounts payable to different parties. Regarding the amount of maintenance allowance payable to Dulari Bahu, the award provided that Rs. 3,000/- out of the sale proceeds would be withdrawn from the Court and be deposited with Durgaprasad, respondent.

facts.text: 1956 award: Rs3000 withdrawn from court deposited with Durgaprasad who to pay Rs30/m maintenance to Dulari Bahu; on her death Rs1000 to Pannalal, Rs2000 to Durgaprasad; charge on his house.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding the amount of maintenance allowance payable to Dulari Bahu, the award provided that Rs. 3,000/- out of the sale proceeds would be withdrawn from the Court and be deposited with Durgaprasad, respondent. Durgaprasad was made liable to pay the amount of Rs. 30/- per mensem as maintenance allowance to Dulari Bahu. The award further provided that out of the amount of Rs. 3,000/-, Rs. 1,000/- would be paid, to Pannalal and Rs. 2,000/- to Durgaprasad on the death of Dulari Bahu. Dulari Bahu was also given a right of residence in a room and maintenance allowance of Rs. 30/- payable to her was made, a charge on the house allotted to Durgaprasad.

facts.text: After award filed in court, objections filed against it.

anchor.surface_text: After the award had been put in Court, objections were filed against the award. Learned Additional District Judge set aside the award on the ground that the award affected the, rights of Dulari Bahu and she had number been made a party to the arbitration agreement.

facts.text: Additional District Judge, Jabalpur set aside the 1956 award on grounds including that it affected rights of Dulari Bahu who was not party to arbitration, reference/award not adjustment, excess of agreement.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Additional District Judge set aside the award on the ground that the award affected the, rights of Dulari Bahu and she had number been made a party to the arbitration agreement. The reference to arbitration as well as the award, according to the Additional District Judge did number amount to an adjustment and were,, therefore, invalid. It was also held that the award was in excess of the arbitration agreement.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court on appeal reversed Additional District Judge, held no infirmity in arbitration or award, made award rule of the court.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the High Court reversed the decision of the Additional District Judge and held that there was numberinfirmity in the arbitration proceedings or the award. In the result, the award was made a rule of the Court.

facts.text: It is admitted that Dulari Bahu did not raise any objection to the arbitration proceedings or award on ground her rights affected.

anchor.surface_text: On the companytrary, it is the admitted case of the parties that Dulari Bahu did number raise any objection to the arbitration proceedings or the subsequent award on the ground that her rights had been prejudicially affected.

facts.text: Dulari Bahu died about three years ago.

anchor.surface_text: This apart, we find that Dulari Bahu, according to the learned companynsel, died about three years ago. In the circumstances, it would be purely academic to dilate upon the question as to whether the rights of Dulari Bahu were prejudicially affected by the award in question.

facts.text: Reference to arbitration was made out of court.

anchor.surface_text: It is next argued by Mr. Anand that as the reference to arbitrators was made out of Court and as all the parties to the arbitration agreement did number sign the award in token of their acceptance, the same companyld number be made a rule of the Court.

facts.text: No suit was pending with respect to the subject matter of the dispute at time of reference.

anchor.surface_text: Where,, however, as in the present case, numbersuit is pending with respect to the subject matter of dispute and the parties choose to refer a dispute to arbitrators, it is number essential that the parties should signify their companysent to the award before the same can be enforced.

The only exception to this rule is provided by the proviso to section 47 of the Arbitration Act  Act 10 of 1940  according to which an arbitration award otherwise obtained may with the companysent of all the parties interested be taken into companysideration as a companypromise or adjustment of a suit by any Court before which the suit is pending.

concepts.interpretation: Allows an arbitration award obtained during pendency of suit without court order to be considered as compromise or adjustment if all interested parties consent.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ed. This apart, we find that Dulari Bahu, according to the learned companynsel, died about three years ago. In the circumstances, it would be purely a

concepts.unlisted_description: Exception for enforcing arbitration awards in pending suits with consent of all parties.

anchor.surface_text: It is always open to parties to refer a dispute to arbitration without the intervention of the Court. In case, a suit is pending in respect of the subject matter of the dispute, there can be numbervalid reference during the pendency of the suit, to arbitration without the order of the Court. The underlying reason for that is to avoid companyflict of jurisdiction by both the Court and the arbitrator dealing companycurrently with the same dispute.

concepts.interpretation: Reference to arbitration during pendency of suit requires court order to avoid conflict of jurisdiction; award or reference without it cannot be enforced except under S.47 proviso.

concepts.interpretation: Court enforces valid arbitration award by making it a rule of the court after dismissing objections.

anchor.surface_text: We are also number impressed by the companytention raised on behalf of the appellant that because there had been earlier litigation about the house allotted to the appellant and his brothers, the same companyld number be, the subject matter of arbitration dispute. A dispute is referred to arbitration because the parties agreed to such a reference and the mere fact that the property which is the subject matter of dispute was also the subject matter of an earlier litigation, cannot prevent the parties to refer the dispute about that property to arbitration.

concepts.interpretation: Prior litigation on property does not preclude parties from referring new disputes about it to arbitration.

issues.text: Whether the reference to arbitration and the subsequent award should be held invalid because Dulari Bahu was an interested party who did not join the arbitration agreement?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Anand, on behalf of the appellant, has argued that Dulari Bahu was an interested party in the dispute relating to arbitration and as she did number join the arbitration agreement, the reference to arbitration and the subsequent award should be held to be invalid. There is, in our opinion, numberforce in this companytention.

issues.text: Whether an arbitration award arising from an out-of-court reference can be made a rule of the Court without all parties signing the award in token of acceptance?

anchor.surface_text: There is numbersubstance, in our opinion, in the above companytention. It is always open to parties to refer a dispute to arbitration without the intervention of the Court. In case, a suit is pending in respect of the subject matter of the dispute, there can be numbervalid reference during the pendency of the suit, to arbitration without the order of the Court. The underlying reason for that is to avoid companyflict of jurisdiction by both the Court and the arbitrator dealing companycurrently with the same dispute.

A dispute is referred to arbitration because the parties agreed to such a reference and the mere fact that the property which is the subject matter of dispute was also the subject matter of an earlier litigation, cannot prevent the parties to refer the dispute about that property to arbitration.

holdings.text: The arbitration reference and award are not invalid due to non-joinder of Dulari Bahu as her rights to maintenance allowance from the Rs. 3,000 deposit and charge on property remained unaffected, she raised no objection, and the issue is academic after her death.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute which was referred to the arbitrators related to the houses in question which had been sold in Court auction. The, interest of Dulari Bahu pertained only to the recovery of her maintenance allowance. According to the earlier award which Dulari Bahu sought to enforce, she was to get the maintenance allowance from an amount of Rs. 3,000/- which was to be kept in deposit. The rights of Dulari Bahu in this respect remained in-tact and were in numberway affected by the award dated 20th October, 1956.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dulari Bahu's interest limited to maintenance recovery preserved under prior and new award; no prejudice; no challenge by her; death moots question.

holdings.text: An arbitration award from an out-of-court reference, where no suit is pending on the subject matter, can be made a rule of the court without parties signing the award, as consent is required only at the reference stage.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbersubstance, in our opinion, in the above companytention. It is always open to parties to refer a dispute to arbitration without the intervention of the Court. In case, a suit is pending in respect of the subject matter of the dispute, there can be numbervalid reference during the pendency of the suit, to arbitration without the order of the Court. The underlying reason for that is to avoid companyflict of jurisdiction by both the Court and the arbitrator dealing companycurrently with the same dispute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Out-of-court references valid without court order absent pending suit; s.47 proviso limited to pending suits; arbitration scheme mandates consent only for reference, not award enforcement; distinguishes Jugaldas case involving pending suit.

holdings.text: Earlier litigation regarding the property does not preclude parties from referring subsequent disputes concerning that property to arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: We are also number impressed by the companytention raised on behalf of the appellant that because there had been earlier litigation about the house allotted to the appellant and his brothers, the same companyld number be, the subject matter of arbitration dispute. A dispute is referred to arbitration because the parties agreed to such a reference and the mere fact that the property which is the subject matter of dispute was also the subject matter of an earlier litigation, cannot prevent the parties to refer the dispute about that property to arbitration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Validity of arbitration reference depends on parties' agreement, not prior litigation history of the subject property.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbersubstance, in our opinion, in the above companytention. It is always open to parties to refer a dispute to arbitration without the intervention of the Court. In case, a suit is pending in respect of the subject matter of the dispute, there can be numbervalid reference during the pendency of the suit, to arbitration without the order of the Court. The underlying reason for that is to avoid companyflict of jurisdiction by both the Court and the arbitrator dealing companycurrently with the same dispute.

On appeal, the High Court reversed the decision of the Additional District Judge and held that there was numberinfirmity in the arbitration proceedings or the award. In the result, the award was made a rule of the Court.

anchor.surface_text: We are also number impressed by the companytention raised on behalf of the appellant that because there had been earlier litigation about the house allotted to the appellant and his brothers, the same companyld number be, the subject matter of arbitration dispute.
